fields.headline: News in brief
fields.bodyText: End of Pan Am as Libyan payout is distributed The remnants of the airline Pan Am will disappear next month as liquidators distribute a long-awaited settlement paid by the Libyan government as compensation for the Lockerbie bombing in 1988 in which 270 died when terrorists detonated a bomb on a flight over the Scottish town. Some 15,000 creditors will share a $30m (£16m) payout from Colonel Gadafy's regime to the Pan Am Liquidation Trust. The distribution ends a 15-year financial saga since Pan Am stopped flying in 1991. It went bust after losing its reputation over the Lockerbie disaster. Andrew Clark in New York Matalan's new clothes put brake on sales decline Discount chain Matalan, soon to be taken private by founder John Hargreaves, has slowed its sales decline and maintained market share. In the nine weeks to October 28 total sales edged ahead by 0.6%. There was an underlying decline of 2% but this is an improvement on the 3.9% decline in the six weeks to October 7. Profits for the six months to August 26 fell by 6.5% to £28.7m, slightly below some analysts' expectations. The group highlighted a "robust" performance in clothing, which is 80% of its business, and is planning new and simplified offerings in its troubled housewares department. Fiona Walsh North Sea divers strike after rejecting 20% offer More than 900 divers in the North Sea oil and gas industry have begun an indefinite strike after rejecting their latest pay offer. Two-thirds of RMT members rejected the three-year deal yesterday, ignoring advice from union bosses to accept a 20% pay rise with 5% more in April. The vote follows the rejection of a previous offer in September. Bob Crow, RMT general secretary, said: "North Sea divers do a particularly difficult job in a hazardous industry yet over two decades their earnings have slipped by 20% in the average pay tables, while the oil and gas companies have been raking in super-profits." Press Association Pensions boom fuels best Friends Provident result Friends Provident beat City expectations yesterday with a 40% surge in third-quarter life and pensions sales and said its UK market share had reached its highest ever figure of 6.9% in the second quarter. Boosted by the overhaul of the pensions market, total UK new business was up by 34% to £3bn in the first nine months of the year, while new overseas business soared by 51% to £1.6bn. The chief executive of Friends Provident Life and Pensions, Ben Gunn, said: "These results clearly demonstrate our ability to drive growth in both the UK and international businesses." Shares closed up 13p at 207p. Fiona Walsh Standard Life backs the favourite for finance post David Nish, a former director of ScottishPower, today joins Standard Life as finance director. Mr Nish was the favourite to succeed Alison Reed, who left recently after 16 months in the job. Announcing the appointment yesterday, Sir Brian Stewart, chairman of the Edinburgh-based insurer, said: "David is an excellent addition to the board. He brings extensive experience as a finance director, with broad skills from working with major UK listed companies." Mr Nish, 46, was ScottishPower's finance director for six years until 2005. His new job includes a salary of £475,000 and bonuses. Rupert Jones UBS given $6bn lesson for dismal third quarter UBS, the world's second-largest bank, yesterday saw $6bn (£3.15bn) wiped off its value after reporting a 21% slump in third quarter net profit to Sfr2.2bn (£900,000). The Swiss-based bank blamed weaker markets in equities and bond trading in early summer for its performance, which fell well below its own forecasts. The shares were 5.1% lower at Sfr74.30 on the SWX exchange, having earlier fallen by 6%. UBS said its net profit compared with Sfr3.15bn in the second quarter of this year and Sfr2.8bn in the third quarter of 2005 but insisted a pick-up in the final quarter put it on track for a record year. David Gow
